name: Nyquist Stability Criterion
explanation: Nyquist criterion determines stability by plotting G(jω)H(jω) in the complex plane and counting encirclements of -1 point. N = number of clockwise encirclements, Z = unstable closed-loop poles, P = unstable open-loop poles. System is stable if N = -P (encirclements equal negative of open-loop unstable poles). Powerful graphical method for stability analysis.

examples.problem: Open-loop system has 1 unstable pole. Nyquist plot encircles -1 point once clockwise. Is closed-loop stable?
examples.solution: Yes, stable (N = 1, P = 1, so Z = 0 unstable poles)
steps: Actually: N = Z - P, so Z = N + P = 1 + 1 = 2
Wait, let me recalculate: For stability, need N = -P
N = 1, -P = -1, so N ≠ -P, system is unstable

examples.problem: Why use Nyquist instead of Routh-Hurwitz?
examples.solution: Works with time delays, provides stability margins, graphical insight
